transcripts.text: To get all my permits, they wanted to take my name off of the building because I didn't believe that I was 14 that could have a building like this.

Mason Wright owns Mason's Super Dogs, which recently celebrated its grand opening event.  And it's pretty quiet here right now, but that's only because they sold out of hot dogs for the second time this week.

For 14-year-old Mason Wright, who reportedly happens to be the youngest restaurant owner in Georgia, running his own business has been a dream in the making since he was nine years old.  Wright says he first tried searching for traditional job opportunities with no success.  The very people who told him no, he said, motivated Wright to create a career path for himself.
So I told myself I can be my own businessman.  So I started walking dogs, washing cars, and mowing lawns.

When Wright turned 10, he bought his own hot dog stand after being inspired by street vendors during a trip to New York City.  The young entrepreneur then had the chance to audition for season 10 of the ABC TV show Shark Tank at Atlanta's Morehouse College.  For Wright, the outcome didn't match what he'd hoped.
I was stumbling on my words, and I couldn't remember anything.  And so they just showed me out of the room.
But as fate would have it, Wright was in the right place at the right time.

I went to the bookstore and the president of Morehouse was actually at the bookstore.  And I told him my pitch and he said I could work on his campus.  when every time I had good grades on my report card.
The college had a contract with the food service company Aramark that allowed Wright to sell on campus.  Still, the experience at Morehouse didn't come without its challenges.
A lot of the times they would call the inspector on me thinking that I didn't have all my certificates because I was very young.

But when they came and they saw that I had everything that I needed to have, After selling hot dogs from his stand, Wright wanted to expand his business to its very own restaurant location.  Again, he found himself facing a set of roadblocks.

To get all my permits, they wanted to take my name off of the building because I didn't believe that I was 14 that I could have a building like this.  But after that, to get my name back on, that took three months.

It's been a long journey, but Mason's Super Dogs is now up and running in Stonecrest, Georgia.  He says supportive mentors like Jay Bailey, president and CEO of the Russell Center for Innovation and Entrepreneurship, helped make it all possible.

This young man has to kind of support networks.  He's not afraid to ask for help.  He's not afraid to call me at 10 o'clock at night and say, you know, Mr.  J, I got a question about something or I need some help.  That kind of tenacity, you can't really teach.  It's in somebody.  He's got it.

Wright says his grand opening event on October 17th was a success.  Judging by the long line of hungry customers, Mason's Super Dogs looks to be a hit.  Mom, are we all out?  Customers may choose from chicken, beef, and vegan options.
With my hot dog stand, you get something you would never think to put on a hot dog, like Philly cheesesteak pizza or chopped chicken.
He added that he's proud to serve both quality and tasty food.
When someone grabs a Mesa Superdog, that they expect the best and they receive the best.
Mason says he hopes to study engineering at Morehouse College and plans to continue growing Mason's Super Dogs in the meantime.  Reporting in Stonecrest, Ashley Williams for Atlanta Black Star.
